toxins.name: Solanine (specifically a glycoalkaloid)
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Acetylcholinesterase Inhibition: Solanine inhibits the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which is responsible for breaking down acetylcholine in the nervous system. This leads to an overstimulation of the parasympathetic nervous system, potentially causing neurological symptoms like tremors, ataxia (loss of coordination), and lethargy12.
    ◦ Cytotoxicity: It interacts with cell membranes (phospholipids), increasing permeability and causing the destruction of cells, particularly in the intestinal lining. This results in severe gastrointestinal irritation, vomiting, and diarrhea3.
    ◦ Mitochondrial Impairment: It disrupts the energy balance of cells by inhibiting the respiratory chain4.
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ Concentration: The highest concentrations are found in the foliage (leaves and stems) and unripe (green) fruits5.... Ripe bell peppers contain very low levels and are generally considered less dangerous, though they can still be irritating9.
    ◦ Potency: Cats are noted to be more sensitive to solanine than dogs due to their limited liver detoxification capacity

toxins.name: Capsaicin (or Capsaicinoids)
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Mucosal Irritation: Capsaicin is a potent irritant to mucous membranes. Upon contact or ingestion, it causes an intense burning sensation, hypersalivation (drooling), coughing, and watering of the eyes911.
    ◦ Gastrointestinal Distress: It irritates the gastrointestinal tract, leading to gastroenteritis, vomiting, and diarrhea512.
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ Concentration: Found primarily in the mature fruits (the peppers themselves)512.
    ◦ Potency: Toxicity varies by the "spiciness" of the pepper. Spicy chili and ornamental peppers are particularly dangerous due to higher capsaicin content, while mild bell peppers are considered "rather harmless" but still not recommended for feeding

toxins.name: Scopoletin
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ The sources group scopoletin with solanine in the foliage, noting that it contributes to gastrointestinal irritation causing vomiting and diarrhea12.
4. Notes on

symptoms.name: Vomiting, Diarrhea, and Hypersalivation (Drooling)
symptoms.notes: Solanine acts as a severe irritant to the intestinal lining, potentially causing inflammation (gastroenteritis). Capsaicin in spicy peppers causes an immediate burning sensation that can lead to drooling and vomiting.Abdominal Pain

symptoms.name: Abdominal Pain (Colic)
symptoms.notes: A cat may show a tense abdominal wall or vocalize pain upon palpation. This is a common progression after the initial vomiting phase.Mucosal Irritation (Burning & Coughing)

symptoms.name: Burning sensation, Coughing, Watery Eyes
symptoms.notes: Specific to capsaicin found in chili and ornamental peppers. Contact can cause conjunctivitis (eye irritation), and inhalation or swallowing can trigger a cough reflex and intense burning of the mouth and throat.Neurological Effects (Apathy to Seizures)

symptoms.name: Lethargy (Apathy), Ataxia (Loss of coordination), Tremors, Seizures
symptoms.notes: These symptoms are caused by solanine (found in the green parts of the plant), which inhibits the enzyme acetylcholinesterase. This disrupts nerve signal transmission, leading to drowsiness, confusion, paralysis, or convulsions in severe cases.Cardiovascular Abnormalities

symptoms.name: Bradycardia (Slow heart rate), Arrhythmias
symptoms.notes: In high doses (associated with eating the plant/foliage), the toxins can disrupt heart rhythm and lead to circulatory collapse.Respiratory Paralysis

symptoms.name: Difficulty breathing (Dyspnea) leading to Respiratory Paralysis
symptoms.notes: In fatal cases of nightshade/solanine poisoning, death is typically caused by respiratory failure.Hematological Changes (Hemolysis)

symptoms.name: Hemolysis (Red blood cell destruction), Hemoglobinuria (Dark urine)
symptoms.notes: Severe poisoning can cause red blood cells to break down, leading to anemia and dark red or brown urine. The released hemoglobin can subsequently damage the kidneys.

treatments.name: Gastrointestinal Decontamination (Emesis or Gastric Lavage)
treatments.description: If the ingestion was recent (typically within 1–2 hours) and the cat is stable, the veterinarian may induce vomiting using medication (such as xylazine) to remove the plant material from the stomach. Alternatively, gastric lavage (stomach pumping) may be performed under anesthesia to wash out the stomach contents.
treatments.notes: This is the primary defense to prevent toxin absorption. Do not attempt to induce vomiting at home, as this can cause further injury or aspiration. This step is usually skipped if the cat is already vomiting severely or is neurologically unstable.

treatments.name: Toxin Adsorption (Activated Charcoal)
treatments.description: Administration of medical-grade activated charcoal (1–4 g/kg) into the digestive tract. This substance binds to the remaining toxins (solanine/glycoalkaloids) in the gut, preventing them from entering the bloodstream.
treatments.notes: Because solanine can undergo "enterohepatic recirculation" (where it is reabsorbed by the body), multiple doses of charcoal may be given every 4–6 hours. A cathartic (medication to speed up bowel movements) is often given with the first dose to help expel the bound toxins.

treatments.name: Fluid Therapy (Intravenous Fluids)
treatments.description: The administration of crystalloid fluids directly into the vein (IV) to rehydrate the cat and maintain electrolyte balance.
treatments.notes: This is critical for two reasons: 1) To replace fluids lost through the severe vomiting and diarrhea caused by both solanine and capsaicin. 2) To stimulate diuresis (urination), which helps flush toxins from the body and protects the kidneys from damage, especially if hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells) has occurred.

treatments.name: Symptomatic Drug Therapy (Atropine & Gastroprotectants)
treatments.description: Using specific medications to treat symptoms as they arise. Atropine may be used to treat slow heart rate (bradycardia) or other cholinergic neurological signs. Antiemetics (to stop vomiting) and gastroprotectants are used to soothe the stomach lining.
treatments.notes: While there is no specific antidote for solanine, atropine can counteract some of its neurological effects. For Chili/Ornamental peppers specifically, which contain capsaicin, cool water irrigation or oral vegetable/mineral oil may be used to soothe the intense burning irritation of the mouth and throat.
